Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Improved Vehicle Autonomy in Geophysical Flows

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Networks of autonomous underwater and surface vehicles (AUVs and ASVs) allow direct and continuous monitoring of the ocean. New deployment strategies are needed to obtain maximum coverage from a relatively small number of vessels. This will require better understanding of the structures controlling transport in geophysical flows such as ocean currents. New results show that AUV/ASV motion planning and adaptive sampling strategies are improved by incorporating models of ocean current dynamics. However, these currents change continually and apparently unpredictably, and this makes it highly challenging to take full advantage. The goals of this project are to better understand the dynamics of the dominant structures in ocean currents, and to explore their impact on AUV/ASV autonomy. Additionally, this work will produce robust motion control strategies for both single vehicles and teams of vehicles, to track desired structure boundaries, while leveraging the environmental dynamics to prolong operational lifespan.

In pursuit of the project goals, the research objectives are to: 1) identify and evaluate key kinematic features that control transport in oceanic surface flows of greatest relevance to autonomous vehicle navigation and control, 2) develop a general mathematical and control framework for teams of autonomous vehicles that leverages key transport controlling features in oceanic flows for improved navigation and monitoring of dynamic and uncertain environments, and 3) apply the control framework to the tracking of salt wedge fronts using the WHOI Jetyaks to establish the transition from the laboratory to the ocean. This work has a significant experimental component that leverages the PIs' existing research infrastructure. The work addresses the theoretical and experimental challenges needed to develop a general mathematical and control framework for applying geophysical fluid dynamics to the development of novel planning, navigation, and control strategies for individual and networked teams of autonomous vehicles.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project involved theoretical, computational, and experimental studies of the dynamics of the dominant structures in ocean flows as well as explorations into how these dynamics affect the autonomy of unmanned vehicles and sensors operating in the ocean. The research has established new techniques for understanding kinematic features in geophysical fluid dynamics (GFD) that govern transport in ocean flows, and has provided a framework for implementing control of autonomous vehicles in noisy environments. Important outcomes from the project include:

Control of Vehicle Escape: We have shown explicitly how to employ a strategy to control the  inter-gyre switching time of a vehicle or sensor operating in a noisy gyre flow. The  control strategy is derived from a framework based on large fluctuation theory which is used to characterize the mean escape time in uncontrolled dynamical systems. The control can be used to enhance or abate the mean escape time.

Achieving a Desired Escape Time: In addition to developing a control strategy that allows one to increase or decrease the vehicle escape time, we have developed a way to achieve a desired escape time. Using theoretical analysis, we showed that the control strategy is able to achieve any desired escape time in an interval governed by the maximum available control. Parameters of the control strategy can be chosen even in environments where full knowledge of the flow dynamics and stochasticity is unavailable. Moreover, the control strategy is effective in environments that exhibit non-Gaussian noise, as well as general dynamical systems that exhibit rare, noise-induced transitions.

Identification of Transport Controlling Features: We have used our experimental low Reynolds number flow tank coupled with particle imaging velocimetry and diagnostic tools including finite-time Lyapunov exponents (FTLE) to characterize the attracting and repelling Lagrangian coherent structures (LCS) for a variety of realistic ocean-like flows. In addition we have performed computational and experimental studies of how inertial particles aggregate with respect to LCS for a range of Stokes numbers and density ratios.  We have shown how this GFD-derived knowledge of the environment can significantly improve the overall quality of vehicle autonomy such as planning energy  efficient trajectories and maintaining sensors in their desired monitoring regions.

The results obtained from these studies form the basis for improved understanding of how one can apply geophysical fluid dynamics to the development of novel planning, navigation, and control strategies for individual and networked teams of autonomous vehicles. The results improve our ability to forecast weather and climate events and to predict a variety of physical processes in geophysical flows, enable improved ocean monitoring and uncertainty prediction over large regions, and improve understanding of contaminant and particulate transport. Outcomes from the research project were presented at conferences and seminars, and have been published/submitted in referred scientific journals and proceedings including SIAM Journal on Applied Dynamical Systems, Physical Review Fluids, and Robotics: Science and Systems Conference.

The project supported three masters students. The students were taught a variety of skills, including theoretical, computational, and experimental methods, reading and understanding the existing scientific literature, writing, and presenting their work. These skills will be beneficial to them in their future careers.
